item.title: Divergence in regulations after Brexit: Copyright law as a preview of future changes.
item.description:
Martin Kretschmer, Professor of Intellectual Property Law (CREATe Centre, University of Glasgow) The UK’s departure from the European Union has resulted in the first instance of regulatory divergence. item.title: The CJEU ruling in McFadden: Public Wi-Fi and Responsibility for Unauthorized Downloads
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex A recent Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) case, McFadden, examined whether businesses offering free wi-fi are responsible for customers’ illegal downloads. This case centered around Article 12 of the EU’s eCommerce Directive, which protects “mere conduits” of information from liability. While generally aligning with existing laws, the ruling raised potentially significant points regarding injunction costs and internet access provision requirements...

item.title: Singapore has modified its regulations for the protection of designs
item.description:
Singapore’s Ministry of Law (MinLaw) has introduced the Registered Designs (Amendment) Bill to Parliament for its first reading. The bill aims to modernize Singapore’s design protection laws by reflecting current design and technology developments. It seeks to foster growth in the design sector by streamlining the process for designers to safeguard their creations. This bill stems from a joint review of Singapore’s registered designs system by MinLaw and the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS)...

item.title: Could this be a parody? The Advocate-General's viewpoint on the Deckmyn case.
item.description:
Sabine Jacques, a PhD student at the University of Nottingham’s School of Law specializing in parody exceptions, discusses the Advocate-General’s (AG) opinion on the Deckmyn case. The case grapples with the interpretation of copyright exceptions for parodies within EU law, specifically Article 5(3)(k) of the Infosoc Directive, which permits member states to allow exceptions for caricature, parody, or pastiche. Jacques highlights the timely relevance of the opinion, given the ongoing debate over copyright exceptions and the delayed implementation of a parody exception in the UK...

item.description:
Microsoft is urging consumers and small businesses to be cautious when buying software, warning them about the risks of accidentally purchasing and using counterfeit products. This advisory comes after a recent raid on a computer vendor in Kembangan Plaza by the Intellectual Property Rights Branch (IPRB) of the Singapore Police Force. The shop in question had been advertising unauthorized “Microsoft license keys” as genuine and offering computers bundled with counterfeit software at heavily discounted prices through their online store...
